content:
You don't give us much to go on here, but such error messages usually indicate that there's a problem on the email service's end, or you have Thunderbird set up with incorrect server settings. If it's their problem, it might be worth a call to them to see if there is a service outage.

You should also check with their tech support or help web page to confirm that your server settings are correct. Many ISPs are outsourcing their email service to other companies like Yahoo, and I am noticing that they sometimes don't bother to tell their existing customers!

If you tell us who is your email provider and your server settings (screen shots would be OK,) we might be able to advise you further.
creator: rednoise

content: If you reinstalled without having deleted the appdata\roaming\thunnderbird folder, it may still be there. Try this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - you are now in windows file explorer, click the back arrow once - you should now be looking at the appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder - open the profiles folder - now, open each of the profiles there, looking for a file named abook.sqlite that has a recently used date. note the folder where you found it. - now, in thunderbird, click tools>import>import from a file - follow the prompts for addressbook until you reach the menu where 'sqlite' is an option. - click the sqlite option and then locate/select the abook.sqlite file you discovered - repeat the tppls>import steps to also import a file named history.sqlite from the same folder as the one in which you found the abook.sqlite file

content:
Carol Anne, your description of your problem is difficult to understand and I think that the title is most misleading. You don't need "pop-ups to see images in your emails"... My understanding is that you want to tell us "why do my emails are displayed in a new window when I double-click them in order to open and read them"... and what you call pop-ups in reality are secondary Thunderbird windows.

Let's go back to your screen shot: what I see is a Thunderbird main window in the background and an email opened in a second window in the foreground. The Thunderbird main window has the "Classic View" layout (see my image), but it has no message pane. By some unfortunate operation the message pane must have been hidden. When the message pane is hidden the thread pane takes all the place on the right and you have to double-click on a message in the thread pane to open it either in a new tab or a new window. I can also see that you activated the Quick Filter toolbar and that you made a search for "suppor" but I don't think that the Quick Filter toolbar is your first concern.

I still think that before this issue occurred you used to open your emails by a simple left click and you read them in the message pane, which is no longer visible as the lower right pane in the main window in your screen shot. So I can only repeat my advise from yesterday: Verify that the Thunderbird main window is in the foreground (or in focus) and hit the F8 key or go to menu View > Layout and select Message Pane (image)

Or is it possible that I followed a bad trail from the beginning and that you really only want to to view images you received in emails?
creator: Mapenzi

content:
A few things I would try...

- Restart Thunderbird in Troubleshooting Mode (Help | Troubleshooting Mode.) Does the problem go away? That might indicate a conflict with an Add-On, or other problem.

- Turn off Hardware Acceleration ( Settings | General, scroll down to bottom.) Hardware acceleration can sometimes cause display anomalies, and I find it makes little performance difference.

- Clear Thunderbird's cache ( Settings | General | Network & Disk Space | Disk Space, click "Clear Now" button.) This probably won't make a difference, but it won't hurt.

- Exclude your Profile directory from your anti-virus, if possible.

- Do a non-destructive check on your physical hard disk. Sometimes excessive slowness can be in indication of a failing hard disc. ( Windows Start button | Computer | right-click on the C: drive, choose Properties, Tools, Error-checking, Check now, UN-tick "automatically fix file system errors, click Start. If it finds errors, you can decided whether to run it again and let it fix the errors.)

content:
I see two possible problems: - normally, email providers want the full email address in settings, yet you just have jhr as user name. Using the full email address should be tried. I also suggest changing port 110 to 995 and authentication to SSL/TLS. - also, your other screenshot indicates you have four email accounts with the provider. It is possible that you have the wrong SMTP server set for the accounts. You did not create a screenshot of the SMTP server setting. You can check that with these steps: - click ';account settiings' - highlight the account name in question in left sidebar - now, on lower right side of screen is a button 'edit SMTP server' click that - it should show the email address associated with that particular account. My guess is that it does not. I suggest also putting the full email address in the DESCRIPTION field for documentation, set port to 465 and authentication to SSL/TLS. - I also suggest repeating this for all four accounts. Each SMTP server pane must reflect the email address of the account, and your post indicated you are receiving message that it is set wrong.

After change, please post back with any error messages and screenshot of SMTP server settings pane for the account.

content:
The first, easy, thing to try is to make sure you're subscribed to the folder. Right-click on the account name in the left accounts list pane. Choose "Subscribe". If you don't see your missing folder listed, click the "Refresh" button. If it reappears, make sure it's checked. It should now appear in the regular list of folders.

=

If that doesn't work, maybe the folder name has exceeded Windows's path length limit. The way I would do get it back requires the add-on ImportExportTools NG, found at:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/

First locate the "missing" folder file. On my Windows computer, with an IMAP email account, it would be found in

"C:\Users\<my logon name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<my Thunderbird profile>\ImapMail\<the account in question>"

You should find a pair of files with the name of the missing folder, one with no extension, one with .msf. Copy the no-extension file to another convenient location on the computer. You may rename the copy with a shorter name at this time.

Folder ("mbox" files) can only be imported to a Local Folder. Right-click on the Local Folders heading in the accounts list pane and choose <ImportExportTools NG | Import MBOX files | Individual MBOX files> and navigate to the folder copy you made. It will import it to a Local Folder. This folder can then be moved to an IMAP account if you wish.

content:
Thunderbird doesn't have and never had a native "auto-correct" feature. Long times ago there had been an add-on "TB Auto-correct 0.0.6.2" written by Frank DiLecce in 2005 which I actively used later https://forums.mozfr.org/viewtopic.php?p=720079#p720079 It had a very limited thesaurus which could be modified/completed by the user, a bit like the personal dictionary in modern TB versions. Later it was replaced by "mms Auto Correct" which worked until TB 52...

If you only want to activate the Thunderbird spell-checker feature (which is not the same as "auto-correct) you have to go to Settings > Composition > Spelling and check ⬜︎ either "Enable spell check as you type" or "Check spelling before sending". But the correction of spell check errors will still have to be executed manually....
creator: Mapenzi

content: With the Windows version, Tools | Settings | Composition | Spelling, you have two options that control the defaults of that feature, "Check spelling before sending" and "Enable spellcheck as you type." You can also temporrily enable/disable "Spellcheck as you type" on a case-by-case basis from the Options menu in the Write window.
creator: rednoise

content: how do i reset password
creator: fran1bill

content: It can't be done from within Thunderbird. You will need to go to your email provider's web site or web mail page to reset your password. Once you have done that you can edit Thunderbird's stored password vault to reflect the new password. In the Windows version, the passwords are stored at <Tools | Settings | Privacy & Security | Passwords | Saved Passwords. It's best to delete the entries for that server - you will be prompted to put in your new password when you next connect to it. Note that there may be multiple entries for that provider - delete all of them. </p>

content: Tools | Address Book, right-click on the address book you want to export, choose Export, in the dialog box, choose an export format that's compatible with whatever you plan to import it into. I recommend .VCF (vCard).
